newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST-Tempered gasoline stock draw seen in APIs.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Tempered gasoline stock draw seen in APIs.

text.p: Tuesday evening's oil inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute (API) is expected to show a seasonal draw in gasoline stocks, but the draw is seen tempered by high output and lacklustre demand, traders said.
"There is a strong seasonal bias for gasoline stock draws, but consumption seems to be leveling out when production is high," said Jim Ritterbusch, Sweeney Oil trader in Illinois.
A Reuters poll of trader estimates forecasted gasoline stocks could show a draw of 500,000 to three million barrels.
The data reflects the week ended March 28.

Gasoline demand begins to rise in the spring until peaking during the summer driving season. Traders said demand for gasoline by retailers built up with much more momentum a year ago, so this year's seasonal draw in the last week in March will not be as steep.

"There has also been a huge amount of imports of (gasoline) feedstock," said Ritterbusch, noting gasoline output has risen sharply in tandem. Refinery runs are expected to rise another 0.25 to 0.50 percentage point after rising a sharp 2.3 percentage points for the week ended March 21.
Even with the increasing in refinery utilization rate, crude stocks are expected to rise by up to three million barrels.
"With demand for crude low in the Europe, North Sea crude has to find somewhere to go," said a Houston crude trader, attributing the rise in crude stocks to an increase in North Sea crude imports.

But, analysts said the amount of crude imports falls within a seasonal trend. U.S. refiners need more crude in the spring to make gasoline. Moreover, gasoline demand is bound to pick up, analysts said.

"I would not write off gasoline just yet. Gasoline demand typically peaks around July and August, and refiners are usually prepared before then," said John Saucer, analyst with Smith Barney in Houston.

Distillate stocks, which include heating oil and diesel, are seen falling a little more than one million barrels. Distillate stocks trend downward in the spring and summer as refiners focus on gasoline output.
